reviewText:
Lumines, Meteos, Every Extended Extra, Rez and Child of Eden. This game is a love letter to Q Entertainment. (Because its not made by them)

Chime is a block dropping game in which not quite Tetris pieces are randomly given to you to place onto the board. The main goal is to create quadrilaterals using the slightly unfamiliar pieces. I should mention the blocks do not actually “drop” You can place them anywhere on the board and as such the possibilities are greater so the game demands your combos and coverage to be better than traditional “falling” block games.

This game takes from Lumines more than the others. You build quadrilaterals and then a timer starts until it becomes solid in which you must add to it before solidification for more points and combo scores. Once solid, a bar that sweeps the screen collects the solid stuff you have made. And this continues until you have amassed enough to unlock the next stage. Its unfortunate that even in free mode you cannot even preview what the next stages song will be as unlocking new stages requires play in the timed mode.

The reason I say it borrows from those games is because of how the gameplay is integrated into the music. The more elaborate the combos the more flare is added to the music; and the music is phenomenal.

THE GIST
I was pretty big into Lumines back during the days of the original PSP. And this game captures some of that original feeling. By that I mean a good but new sort of puzzle game that is not exactly Tetris or in this case not exactly Lumines.

reviewText:
Chime takes me back to the days when Lumines on the PSP was massive... possibly in some small sections of the PSP Puzzle Strategy community.

Ok, so Lumines probably wasn't all that well known outside of the PSP, but essentially you had 2x2 different coloured squares come down, much like tetris. You'd clear the board and score points when you build up 2x2 blocks of the same colour, when a line would slide across the screen and take them out.

In Chime, you don't need to worry about colour, but the pieces are all different configurations of 5 squares connected, much like tetris' 4 squares. You can move, rotate, and place them anywhere on the grid. The 'beatline' will move in time with the music, setting off events when it hits the shapes. If you have a solid blocks of 3x3 or more, they will disappear after a short while, give better music samples, and stamped down a completed section on the grid. The aim is to get 100% coverage on these grids before the time runs out.

This game is great if you want to fill in time, or if you're into mixing a few tunes with samples based on how well you play. Probably a small cult following for that. In the end, since there are only 6 or 7 level/songs to play, it only becomes a grind to try to get 100% coverage on each level, not really much more than that.

Pretty good if on sale, not really something to put in a wishlist though.

6/10

reviewText:
Chime is a cute, little puzzle game that has some heart put into it. You can be as casual or as arcade about the game as you like. It is a good amount of fun for about an hour, allowing replayability with high scores, setting personal goals like clearing the level 3 times before you time out, or even just trying to get the best sounding result. Unfortunately it's hard to find direction in this game without coming up wiht it yourself.

It is unfortunate how there are only 6 songs. If there were 10 songs I'd be satisfied. If there were 30 songs I would buy multiple copies for my friends so we could compete. I understand that this was a game linked to a charity, and there was likely a budget (or a deadline) that had to be kept, but it's really not enough to justify the game on its own for its price. It really is a nice game with lots of potential. Had there been a custom song feature (even if it allowed a maximum of 2 minutes with any custom song) I would've played this game for hours on end.

This is a nice game to get gifted, on sale, or with a coupon, but not for it's entirety of it's price. However, I am very excited for Chime 2 which should be coming out soon, featuring many more songs, levels, and modes. I would reccomend saving your money for the sequel instead of this game. I would consider this game better as an extention to the sequel, but on it's own it's simply not enough.

Chime, it's a 2D puzzle game that will have you trying to fit these 5-square jigsaw pieces onto a platform to complete rectangles. The bigger the rectangle, the bigger the score. When the time runs out, you're done. Except you're not, because Chime will keep sucking you in by making you think that you could have done just that little bit better.

Even though there are only 6 different levels and 3 different difficulties in this game, I found myself replaying them repeatedly. Always thinking that I could beat my previous score if I just concentrated, if I just cut out the mistakes, if I moved just a little bit faster. The friend leaderboards (the global leaderboards are annoyingly topped with cheats) will drive you to try again as you curse that friend who seemingly has an impossible score.

To give you even more encouragement, a special thing happens when you get full coverage on the board. The game gives you a points and time bonus, wipes the boards, and gets you to go again. Your completion percentage is tracked with your high scores so you will always be using this to drive your next attempt. Knowing that you got 5 completions last time, surely this time you'll be able to get 6?

So it's addictive, good. But then there's the music. Provided by some great electronic music artists (like Lemon Jelly and Moby), the music is the backbone of this game. The music is synced to the puzzle board so that beats match a swiper going across the board. When you have a completed rectangle on the board, the shape of the rectangle will trigger a different layer of the music track to be heard. It feels like you are building the track up as you progress through the level. It builds on your sense of accomplishment as you play and it really does put the icing on this rectangled shaped cake.

If you are a puzzle game player and a fan of electronic music, this game is a must-have. The only disappointment you'll have is that there are only 6 tracks (one more than the XBox version thanks to Portal's Still Alive track being added for PC). But don't be surprised if you wake up one day to find you've spent dozens of hours on this game, trying to score that perfect run.

*Purchased during sale as part of the Indie Beat Pack*\n\nThe best way to describe this game is Tetris meets Qix with Music. Each level is considered a song, and each song has a beat which marches across the level as you fill the blank space with Tetris-like blocks. When you fill up at least a 3x3 space (called a Quad), it starts to fill and gives points. You can add to it while it fills, but once it's filled it's done. When the beat bar marches past, the Quad is added to the amount of space filled. 50% fill gives you access to the next level. It's a difficult game to describe, but if you like Tetris, Qix and Music, you really can't go wrong.

reviewText: If you liked Lumines this one is for you.

This is a very relaxing casual game. Its a mixture between tetris and volfied. Use tetris style blocks and arrange them to enable capture coverage of an area. The bigger the area you cover, the better your score will be.

There are a total of 6 stages which can be completed in either timed or free mode. Timed mode basically sets a time in which to complete the stage, and of course more coverage also means more time added. If you manage to to do it, free mode will then be unlocked for you to enjoy the stage at your leisure with no time limit.

The game is simple and relaxing to play. The music is a good eclectic mix of smooth electronica tunes which are actually composed by real life music artistes such as Moby or Orbital. Tis a bit of a shame that there are only 6 stages available for play.

Overall Rating: 7.0 / 10
Probably not worth to buy at full price, but still worth a look if its on sale and if you are looking for a nice relaxing musical tetris like game.

reviewText: I have this on my PS3 and also have Child of Eden, with Lumines & Every Extended Extra on my PSP. This is a very addictive and time consuming game. You might think that getting all the level objectives is easy, yet it is not. Paying attention to creating non-fragment groups is thee most importat adivce I can give. One you have too many fragments you will surely not be able to make it. The key would be to start small and build large to stack that multiplier up high and get massive points before the time runs out. This is all about skill placement and also being able to use the entire board to clear it.\n\nDon't pay attention to neg reviews, if you like skill puzzles this is for you!  I personally also like Dark Souls, Fallout, and more so if that tells you anything I put this game right up there as if it was the Dark Souls of Puzzle Games.
